thread.title: New Englewood superintendent is center of discussion at school board candidates’ forum
thread.title_full: New Englewood superintendent is center of discussion at school board candidates’ forum

title: New Englewood superintendent is center of discussion at school board candidates’ forum
text:
New Englewood superintendent is center of discussion at school board candidates’ forum October 20, 2015, 7:12 PM Last updated: Tuesday, October 20, 2015, 7:33 PM By KIM LUEDDEKE Buy this photo GEORGE MCNISH/Special To the Record Clockwise from top left, Howard Haughton, George Garrison III, Molly Craig-Berry, and Henry Pruitt III, are shown during a forum for the candidates in the Englewood school board election. 
ENGLEWOOD – There were about 30 people who came out for a school board candidates’ forum this week, but it was someone who didn’t make an appearance who had the biggest impact. 
Robert Kravitz, who will start work as Englewood’s schools superintendent next week, was invoked over and over by the candidates in response to questions ranging from increasing parental involvement to whether an outside company should take over management of Dwight Morrow High School. 
“I believe that the superintendent that we have hired is going to bring the resources and the skill sets to the table to make the changes that we need,” said School Board President Howard Haughton. 
Kravitz, on Tuesday, declined to comment on the forum saying he preferred to stay out of the campaign. 
Haughton is one of four candidates competing for three, three-year terms on the school board, along with fellow incumbents Henry Pruitt III and Molly Craig-Berry. Also on the ballot is George Garrison III, who was voted out of office last year after serving two terms on the board. 
The four spoke Monday at a forum hosted by the League of Women Voters. The event was an opportunity for the quartet to make their case why they should be elected, and to take questions from residents. 
The first question — what each candidate perceived as the greatest challenge facing Englewood schools — drew a variety of answers from the candidates. 
Test scores, said Garrison, who called the district’s ranking compared to others “embarrassing.” With a nearly $70 million budget, Garrison said money is not the issue, nor are the teachers and administrators, whom he said he had confidence in. The socioeconomics of the district, where about three-quarters of the students are eligible for free and reduced price lunch, is also not an excuse, he said. 
Garrison was hopeful that Kravitz could “turn things around,” noting that the incoming superintendent oversaw Fort Lee’s School 3 when it was recognized as a National Blue Ribbon School. 
In addition to improving test scores, Pruitt said the district needs to ensure there are opportunities for all students: “Some kids may want to go to Princeton or Harvard or Yale, but other kids may want to do other things,” Pruitt said. 
School officials have discussed using the former St. Cecilia School, which the district rents, for vocational instruction, Pruitt said. 
Craig-Berry agreed that the district needs to raise its academic standards, but said the district also struggled with communication and transparency. She, too, was optimistic that Kravitz would help address these issues. 
“Once you have that stability at the top, then we can really address certain things,” said Craig-Berry. 
Haughton, meanwhile, cited a lack of consistency and engagement from one school to another as the district’s biggest challenge. Test scores tend to decline when children move to a new school and teachers in those grades routinely complain that students are not prepared, said Haughton. 
Kravitz is expected to establish goals and outline a vision for the district, Haughton said. The board’s job is to support him and the staff as they execute those goals, he said. 
The candidates also fielded questions about topics that included funding, student discipline, letting the public vote on the school budget, tying teacher compensation to student performance and making afterschool programs more accessible. 
Another candidates’ forum will be held at 6:45 p.m. Oct. 26 at the Ebenezer Baptist Church of Englewood, 216 4th St. The election is Nov. 3.
